DOC.HEAD: Canada Charges Resident of 38 Years as World War II Criminal
DOC.TEXT: A 72-year-old native of Byleorussia who emigrated to Canada in 1951 has been charged under Canadian war crimes legislation with the murder of 490 people, the Justice Department said Monday. Bill Hobson, chief of the department's war crimes unit, said Michael Pawlowski was arrested at his home in Renfrew, about 60 miles west of Ottawa, and was held pending a bail hearing. Hobson said charges filed in the Supreme Court of Ontario specify eight counts of murder _ four under Criminal Code provisions dealing with war crimes and four with crimes against humanity. The counts accuse Pawlowski of murdering 410 Jews and 80 non-Jewish Poles in 1942, during World War II, in the Byelorussian republic of the Soviet Union. No mention was made as to whether Pawlowski was serving in a military unit at the time. He was charged with murdering 400 Jews in the small village of Snov; 10 more Jews who escaped the first killings; and 80 Poles in the same region. Pawlowski, described as a horticulturist, has lived in the Renfrew area since coming to Canada in 1951; five years later he became a Canadian citizen. Under federal legislation passed two years ago, Canadian residents can be tried here for war crimes or crimes against humanity committed elsewhere. The government has moved against two other people accused as war criminals since 1987. The war crimes unit was set up after a royal commission recommended urgent action against 20 prime suspects who came to Canada after World War II.
